snippet: Research has found that the toothy snouts of freshwater sawfish are covered with receptors to detect the electric fields of other animals and plan an attack.
abstract: Study in journal Current Biology details how the sawfish uses its trademark snout to swiftly and fiercely attack prey, revising common understanding of the sawfish as a lazy bottom dweller.
lead_paragraph: Research has found that the toothy snouts of freshwater sawfish are covered with receptors to detect the electric fields of other animals and plan an attack.

headline.print_headline: Sawfish Have Nose for Attacks, and for Strategy
headline.main: Sawfish Have Nose for Attacks, and for Strategy
